thread.title: Raptors 905 team will have intriguing list of prospects
thread.title_full: Raptors 905 team will have intriguing list of prospects | Toronto Star

author: Doug Smith
title: Raptors 905 team will have intriguing list of prospects
text:
They’ve come to be known as the kids, the young guys, the end-of-the-training-camp-bench guys the Raptors have kept around because of the possibilities they present.
And it’s almost time for them to go home.
To Mississauga.
With the NBA season rapidly approaching, the Raptors are going to have to carve some excess off their training camp roster but they fully expect to retain some of it in the minor leagues.
“They’ve been doing it for the 905s, those guys are doing a good job working and improving,” Raptors coach Dwane Casey said. “The young group that we have, all of them have a lot of value, a lot of them are very talented young men, they just need time in the D-League, time to grow.”
The group is big, bigger than ever for a Toronto franchise because it will have to stock the Raptors 905 D-League team that begins play next month at Mississauga’s Hershey Centre.
There will be players there every now and then who have NBA contracts — Bruno Caboclo, Lucas Nogueira, Delon Wright, Norman Powell and perhaps Anthony Bennett — but the others are just as intriguing.
Axel Toupane, Shannon Scott, Ronald Roberts and Michale Kyser are intriguing prospects the Raptors hope to keep around.
D-League roster rules allow NBA teams to place up to four players who’ve been in the main camp as “affiliate players” to their D-League team, if the players sign D-League contracts.
That’s likely the fate of Toupane, Scott, Roberts and Kyser, although some team officials fear Toupane will be snapped up by another NBA team when he’s placed on waivers sometime on the weekend.
“It’s probably one of the most talented young groups we’ve had,” Casey said.
The players on NBA contracts can be moved back and forth between Toronto and Mississauga at the Raptors leisure. They could practise with Toronto some morning and be force-fed D-League minutes later that night. The others on D-League deals won’t be able to join the parent club without signing an NBA contract until January when the 10-day contract period begins.
But having the non-roster guys close by and keeping them in the family, so to speak, provides the consistency the Raptors want.
“They understand what we’re doing, they know the terminology, they have a great feel for our offensive system, our defensive system,” said Casey.
TV time: The Raptors are splitting all of their broadcasts right down the middle, the team announced Wednesday. TSN and Sportsnet will each have 41 TV and 41 radio games with no change to the crews. Matt Devlin will once again be the sole TV play-by-play voice with Jack Armstrong (TSN) and Leo Rautins (Sportsnet) providing commentary. On radio, Eric Smith and Paul Jones will handle the Sportsnet games with Jones, Armstrong and Sherman Hamilton handling the TSN radio broadcasts.
